results.title: Dutiya vedan sutta - Felt Experiences (Second)
results.description: The Buddha describes how to see the three felt experiences that are experienced on contact through the sense doors - pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

results.title: Taṇhā vagga - Chapter 24 - Craving
results.description: Dhammapada verses 334–359 depict craving as a binding force, likening it to a creeping vine, a trapped hare, and a spider’s web. The wise cut these bonds, free from passion, aversion, illusion, and lo
results.contentSnippet:

wriggle like a trapped hare;
Bound fast by mental fetters,
they <m

results.title: Craving
results.description: A driving ‘thirst’ that reaches out toward experiences, identities, or outcomes as the place to find satisfaction—“if only I had that.” It spins stories of lack, binds the mind to becoming, and invari

results.title: Self Erasure
results.description: A craving to end suffering through erasure of current experience or identity, e.g. “This self is unbearable; I want out.”

results.title: Non Identification
results.description: A quality of mind that does not construct or fabricate a sense of self in relation to experience. It is the absence of the 'I am this' identification—neither claiming ownership nor defining oneself th
synonyms: lit. not made of that state

results.title: Greed
results.description: A grasping mental quality of craving, possessiveness, or lustful wanting that clings to objects or experiences; it fuels attachment and obstructs renunciation and contentment

results.title: Unwise attention
results.description: Attention that misses the point of contact, fixating on concepts or features. Disconnected from the source of experience, it then engages in reactions of craving, aversion, and delusion.

results.title: Recognition of diversity
results.description: The perception of multiplicity and variety in experience—seeing distinct forms, beings, and phenomena as separate entities. While natural to ordinary cognition, when fueled by craving and conceit it p

results.title: Felt Experience
results.description: Pleasant, neutral, or painful sensation—the experience felt on contact. Sometimes translated as “feeling.” Distinct from an emotional state or reaction, it refers to the affective tone of experience,

results.title: Direct knowledge
results.description: A deep, firsthand realization or knowing that arises from personal experience, not from study or conceptual understanding; it is an immediate, unmediated apprehension of truth.

results.title: Immaturity
results.description: A childish lack of discernment that fails to see the results of actions clearly. It delights in surface pleasure and ignores consequence. Immaturity leads to poor choices and association with unwise c

results.title: Speculation
results.description: A form of discursive thought that wanders into conjecture and theorizing, disconnected from direct experience. It involves moving from one idea to another through logic and argument, and is often root
synonyms: analytical thinking disconnected from direct experience

results.title: Tatiya jana sutta - Gives Rise To (Third)
results.description: A deity asks the Buddha what gives rise to a person, what does he have that wanders about, what experiences cyclic existence, and what determines this person‘s destiny.
results.contentSnippet:
[The Blessed One]: “|<mark class="bg-yellow-100 dark:bg-yellow-900 px-1 rounded">Craving</mark>::wanting, yearning, longing, attachment, lit. thirst [taṇha]| gives rise to a person,
his |mind::the fac

results.title: Non Proliferation
results.description: The cessation of the mind's tendency to spin out elaborate stories, interpretations, and conceptual elaborations. In non-proliferation, experience is met simply and directly without the overlay of men

results.title: Mental proliferation
results.description: Mind's tendency to spin out elaborate stories, interpretations, and emotional reactions from simple experiences.

results.title: Happiness
results.description: Bodily ease and comfort; a pleasant feeling experienced with the body. In the third jhāna, one dwells experiencing this pleasure with the body. It is abandoned, along with bodily pain, for the fourth

results.title: Taṇhā sutta - Craving
results.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of craving - 1) craving for sensual pleasures, 2) craving for becoming, and 3) craving for non-becoming.
results.contentSnippet: “Bhikkhus, there are these three kinds of <mark class="bg-yellow-100 dark:bg-yellow-900 px-1 rounded">craving</mark>. What three? <mark class="bg-yellow-100 dark:bg-yellow-900 px-1 rounded">Craving</m

results.title: Diligence
results.description: The protective quality of guarding the mind amidst sensory experience. By restraining the faculties, the mind remains unsoiled by attraction.

results.title: Equanimity
results.description: A state of mental poise and balance, characterized by non-reactivity and composure in the face of agreeable or disagreeable experiences.

results.title: Perceiving gratification
results.description: The contemplative perception that focuses on the attractive or pleasurable aspect of experience, fueling delight and attachment to sense pleasures.

assertions.reason: Topic with both terms in description should rank high
ITI 53 has both terms in content
SN 1.55 has both 'craving' and 'experience' in content
ITI 53 (both terms) should rank above ITI 58 (only craving)
